prop.head.headtext: Thorburn, Law of Confidential Business Information

prop.head.label.name: Chapter
prop.head.headtext: Confidential Business Information and the Employment Relationship

para.paratext: The basic duties of a fiduciary employee are rooted in the employment contract. However, while fiduciary employees are bound to perform in accordance with the contractual terms governing their employment, they also have an expanded and heightened level of duty that goes beyond those owned by mere employees.

As a starting point, a fiduciary employee will be strictly prohibited from engaging in activities that conflict with the interests of the employer's business. The most obvious result of this duty is a strict prohibition from actively competing with the employer while the employment relationship continues. As a result, every act undertaken by a fiduciary prior to departure that prepares him or her to compete with the employer will come under the full scrutiny of the court.[1] The same will be true for a junior level employee who joins with a senior employee in breach of fiduciary obligations.[2]

The fiduciary's higher duty will continue for a reasonable time period following the conclusion of the employment relationship. That duty will often prevent the fiduciary from performing any work for a competitor for a reasonable period of time.[3] Also, fiduciary employees, like all employees, will be restrained from publishing or divulging that which has been communicated to them in confidence. In addition, they cannot make any improper use of information obtained in the course of their former employment.[4]

See Canadian Industrial Distributors Inc. v. Drague (1994), 20 O.R. (3d) 574, 7 C.C.E.L. (2d) 60 (Gen. Div.) and Firemaster Oilfield Services Ltd. v. Safety Boss (Canada), [2001] 4 W.W.R. 256, 87 Alta. L.R. (3d) 366 (Q.B.).

See Hanson v. Clifford (1994), 21 B.L.R. (2d) 108, 59 C.P.R. (3d) 465 (B.C.S.C.), revd 28 B.C.L.R. (3d) 101, 72 C.P.R. (3d) 53 (C.A.), and Procon Mining & Tunnelling Ltd. v. McNeil (2010), 187 A.C.W.S. (3d) 1023, 2010 BCSC 487, supp. reasons 2010 BCSC 1151.
Zesta Engineering Ltd. v. Cloutier, 2010 CarswellOnt 7953, 2010 ONSC 5810, additional reasons 2013 CarswellOnt 410, 2013 ONSC 385.
See Wilcox v. G.W.G. Ltd., [1986] 1 W.W.R. 567, 40 Alta. L.R. (2d) 300 (C.A.); GasTOPS Ltd. v. Forsyth, 2012 CarswellOnt 2539, 2012 ONCA 134.
